awd_titl_txt: Patriot League Institutions Mentor Associate Professors WISEly
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create and study a new model for mentoring of women associate professors in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).  A diverse network of Patriot League Institutions will be involved: Lehigh University, Georgetown University, Bucknell University, Lafayette College, and the United States Military Academy.  These small to mid-sized universities represent a range of missions, Carnegie classifications, geographies, and organizational structures.  This project will address gaps in mentor structures and practices by establishing Faculty Success Fellowships for two cohorts of eligible associate professor women in STEM across the network.  The program includes a peer-mentoring component that includes faculty from across the network of institutions to expand the faculty peer network.  Expected outcomes include: improved perceptions of mentoring and support; improved measures of career satisfaction and progress; enhanced mentoring skills; and campus leaders with understanding about how to align promotion expectations with requirements.

This project is specifically designed to address the many reasons that STEM women faculty remain at associate professor rank longer than men, 1 to 3 years, or 24.2% more, before promotion to full professor (Bilimoira, 2011; MLA 2009; Buch, 2011).  Some of the reasons are tied to inequitable mentoring at the associate faculty level (Buch, 2011).  The intervention is adapted from Lehigh's ADVANCE program, strengthened with information from previous ADVANCE programs, and uniquely refined to each institution's context by local implementation teams.  The Fellowships permit faculty to design and implement a mentored resourced plan of action leading to early success.  The vertical mentoring structure will be reinforced with a peer-to-peer mentoring component to minimize isolation, foster accountability, increase their support networking, provide outside perspectives, and encourage future collaborations.  Administrative leadership (Deans and Department Chairs, as appropriate) is essential to success; the proposal supports their inclusion through ongoing communication.  The iterative evaluation provides insight into existing and evolving attitudes about mentoring, facilitates knowledge about implementation process, and will improve trainings.  The findings will create and advance knowledge about the design and implementation of mentoring programs for mid-career success of women faculty in STEM.  This project will strengthen our understanding of how best to support associate professor faculty to full professor, where most higher education leaders emerge.  

The NSF ADVANCE Partnerships for Learning and Adaptation Networks (PLAN) program track supports projects that promote the adaptation and implementation of previously effective ADVANCE programs in new contexts and the testing of innovative strategies to promote the participation, success, and advancement of women in STEM academic careers.  PLAN projects also contribute to the knowledge base on gender equity in STEM academic careers.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Patriot League Mentoring Associate Professors WISEly (MAPWISEly) project was funded in 2015 to positively impact recently tenured women STEM associate professors' careers and to identify optimal features of faculty mentoring and professional development programs for this mid-career stage.

Nationwide, women are underrepresented on university STEM faculties, and the gender gap widens with each advanced rank. Most mentoring programs address new or pre-tenure faculty. Similar patterns exist at the four partner schools of Lehigh University, Georgetown University, Bucknell University, and Lafayette College. These small to mid-sized institutions represent a range of missions, locations, and organizational structures. Yet, they each wished to strengthen mentoring for associate professors as a key strategy in supporting faculty careers so more women attain the rank of full professor.  

This project addressed gaps in structures and practices of mentoring and professional development programs in several ways. First, across three cohorts, a total of 47 faculty women identified their own mentors. Then, with advice from a mentor, each mentee developed an individual faculty development plan to achieve goals to support progress towards full professor. Modest funding enabled successful implementation of the individual plans. Together, these Faculty Success Fellowships (FSFs) represent a variety of specific professional activities, each of which contribute to the scholarly success or visibility of the mentee (e.g., travel for research or networking, attending external professional leadership programs, support for analytical software or professional editing, and learning new teaching or research techniques, among others). Mentors gave feedback on publications, applying for funding, promotion packets, and navigating the process of promotion itself. 

Because expectations around promotion to full professor can vary dramatically between institutions, campus-specific programming and networks are extremely important. Thus, each site hosted welcome programs and several informal gatherings to bring the mentees together. Additionally, in response to needs identified by the mentees, each campus hosted panel sessions about the criteria for promotion to full professor. 

The project then convened three main cross-campus events designed to expand networks of the mentees. Through these cohort gatherings, the faculty discussed their FSFs and research, gained some preliminary career coaching insights, learned strategies for self-promotion, and enhanced their knowledge about skills of successful grant writing.

The project steering team, composed of influential campus leaders and decision makers across the four partner institutions, also formed a learning community. Specifically, this project enabled learning about equitable service and faculty workloads and core principles of making mentor matches, preparing mentors, and other facets of designing and monitoring a campus-level mid-career mentoring program. The learning outcomes have been disseminated to others on the campuses. 

Because the women who participated in this program had only recently been tenured, the timeline does not permit evaluation of program success in helping them achieve promotion to full professor.  One striking finding emerged, however. The combination of funding (even a modest amount) and an institutionally-sanctioned mandate to work with a mentor appears to have been the most effective aspect of this program.  The FSFs gave newly-tenured women both the motivation and the excuse to reach out to high-status mentors they might not have otherwise approached. The structured and sanctioned nature of the mentoring relationships was also likely a factor in encouraging mentors to participate. The success of this combination of factors may have implications for other universities interested in more effective mid-career mentoring. Thus, the uniqueness of this program lies in its coupling of three elements: funding, a formal mentoring relationship, and a required professional development plan.

The intellectual merit of this project is that other institutions can consider the combination of choice and structure, funding, and preparation of mentors in order to have significant individual impacts on women STEM faculty with modest resources. It is also imperative that mentors have the most current understanding of the institution?s criteria for faculty promotion. Some of the project learnings have already been disseminated via a workshop on Mentoring Mentors and are impacting pilot programs and policies on our campuses. Additional presentations to the ADVANCE community, and the project website, will expand the reach of this work.

Broader Impacts: The recommendations to focus on self-directed, mentored, and funded individual development plans, while equipping mentors and monitoring the program, can help other campuses with their goals of supporting more women in STEM to achieve promotion to full professor. Narrowing the gender gap at the rank of full professor will result in a more diverse set of faculty role models for students, especially women, in STEM. Thus, women students are more likely to see a future for themselves in high-powered positions, regardless of their ultimate career path. Results of this project will impact the diversity of professional leaders in a range of disciplines, both within and beyond science, engineering, and the academic world.
